enigma.console
Interface TextWindow

All Known Implementing Classes:
Java2DTextWindow
public interface TextWindow

A rectangular grid of characters with support for keyboard and mouse events. TextWindow does not provide high-level operations such as text editing or stream input and output, although such operations can be layered on top of it. The Console class wraps a TextWindow to provide these high-level capabilities.

TextWindow is write-only: there is no way to read characters back off of the screen. This is partly to help enforce good design, as that is seldom a reasonable thing to do, and partly because it should be possible to implement TextWindows that use a variety of terminal protocols, most of which do not offer screen-reading functionality.

Java2DTextWindow provides an implementation of TextWindow using the Java2D APIs for its rendering.

Author:
Ethan Royael Nicholas (ethan@ethannicholas.com)
See Also:
Console, DefaultConsoleImpl
Status:
UNSTABLE. Incompatible changes may be introduced in the future, although they are not likely to be drastic.

getTitle

public String getTitle()
Returns the title of this window. Not all TextWindow implementations will display the title for users to see.

See Also:

getCursorX

public int getCursorX()
Returns the column in which the cursor is currently positioned. Cursor position is relevant both because it is generally displayed to the user and because it normally controls where output will show up.

the column in which the cursor is currently positioned

addTextMouseListener

public void addTextMouseListener(TextMouseListener l)
Adds a listener for mouse events. Not all TextWindow implementations will necessarily offer mouse support. TextWindows without mouse support will allow mouse listeners to be added and removed from without error, but will simply never notify the listeners of any events.

It is important to note that the Y coordinate of a TextMouseEvent may be negative when the user has scrolled a TextWindow backwards. Negative Y coordinates indicate lines from the scrollback buffer.

Parameters:
l - the listener to add
See Also:
removeTextMouseListener(enigma.event.TextMouseListener)

removeTextMouseListener

public void removeTextMouseListener(TextMouseListener l)
Removes a mouse listener. It is not an error to attempt to remove a listener which is not currently registered.

Parameters:
l - the listener to remove
See Also:
addTextMouseListener(enigma.event.TextMouseListener)

addTextMouseMotionListener

public void addTextMouseMotionListener(TextMouseMotionListener l)
Adds a listener for mouse motion events. Not all TextWindow implementations will necessarily offer mouse support. TextWindows without mouse support will allow mouse listeners to be added and removed from without error, but will simply never notify the listeners of any events.

It is important to note that the Y coordinate of a TextMouseEvent may be negative when the user has scrolled a TextWindow backwards. Negative Y coordinates indicate lines from the scrollback buffer.

Parameters:
l - the listener to add
See Also:
removeTextMouseMotionListener(enigma.event.TextMouseMotionListener)

output

public void output(char c)

Outputs the specified character at the current cursor position, using the default attributes. The cursor automatically advances to the next position, which may cause the cursor to wrap to the next line or the TextWindow to scroll.

If the character is a newline ('\n'), the cursor is automatically advanced to the next line. A tab ('\t') is expanded to four spaces. No other control characters are supported (for instance, a backspace character does not cause the cursor to move backwards), and unsupported control characters or other unprintable characters will generally render as an error glyph. All TextWindow implementations must support the entire ASCII character set, but support for other character ranges is dependent upon the particular TextWindow implementation.

This method always functions as if in overstrike mode, meaning that the character under the cursor is changed and all other characters are unaffected.

Parameters:
c - the character to output, which should be a printable character, a tab, or a newline

output

public void output(char c,
                   TextAttributes attributes)
As output(char), but uses the specified attributes rather than the default.

Parameters:
c - the character to output, which should be a printable ASCII character, a tab, or a newline
attributes - the TextAttributes with which to render the character
Throws:
NullPointerException - if attributes is null

output

public void output(int x,
                   int y,
                   char c)
As output(char), but outputs the character at the specified position and does not affect the cursor's position or cause the TextWindow to scroll.

Parameters:
x - the column in which to output the character
y - the row in which to output the character
c - the character to output, which should be a printable ASCII character, a tab, or a newline

output

                   int y,
                   char c,
                   TextAttributes attributes)

Parameters:
x - the column in which to output the character
y - the row in which to output the character
c - the character to output, which should be a printable ASCII character, a tab, or a newline
attributes - the TextAttributes with which to render the character
Throws:
NullPointerException - if attributes is null

output

public void output(char[] c,
                   int offset,
                   int count)
As output(char), but outputs every character in the specified section of the character array.

Parameters:
c - the character array from which to output
offset - the position from which to start writing characters
count - the number of characters to output
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if count is negative
IndexOutOfBoundsException - if offset is negative or offset + count is greater than the size of the array

output

public void output(char[] c,
                   int offset,
                   int count,
                   TextAttributes attributes)
As output(char[], int, int), but uses the specified attributes instead of the default.

Parameters:
c - the character array from which to output
offset - the position from which to start writing characters
count - the number of characters to output
attributes - the TextAttributes with which to render the characters
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if count is negative
IndexOutOfBoundsException - if offset is negative or offset + count is greater than the size of the array
NullPointerException - if attributes is null

output

public void output(String s)
As output(char), but outputs every character in the specified string.

Parameters:
s - the string to output

                   TextAttributes attributes)
As output(String), but uses the specified attributes instead of the default.

Parameters:
s - the string to output
attributes - the TextAttributes with which to render the characters
Throws:
NullPointerException - if attributes is null

outputImmediately

public void outputImmediately(char c,
                              TextAttributes attributes)
Similar to output, but requests that the TextWindow paint the character without delay. This method should only be used to display characters as the user types them, so that they appear on the screen faster; the disadvantage of this method is that overall throughput is greatly reduced, so it should never be used to output more than one character per keystroke.

The request to output the character immediately is merely a hint, and TextWindow implementations are free to treat outputImmediately no differently from output.

Parameters:
c - the character to output
attributes - the TextAttributes with which to render the character

insertRow

public void insertRow(int row)
Inserts a blank row at the specified position, moving all prior rows up by one.

Parameters:
row - the position at which to insert a row

pageUp

public void pageUp()
Scrolls the window up one page, if scrolling is supported and the window is not already at the top of its scroll range. Otherwise, this call is ignored.

pageDown

public void pageDown()
Scrolls the window down one page, if scrolling is supported and the window is not already at the bottom of its scroll range. Otherwise, this call is ignored.
